gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
When using this data set, it should be bibliographically referred to as 'Urban Audit, 2004'.
The Urban Audit (UA) provides European urban statistics for a representative sample of large and medium-sized cities across 28 European countries. It enables an assessment of the state of individual EU cities and provides access to comparative information from other EU cities.
This spatial dataset will support the study and dissemination of the UA data. It allows the visualisation of participating cities at three conceptual levels: - UA City - the core city, using an administrative definition - UA City Kernel - a concept introduced to improve comparability between large cities - Larger Urban Zone (LUZ) - approximating the functional urban region The extent of this dataset is the EU-27 (except Ireland) plus Norway and Switzerland.
The URAU dataset contains a polygonal feature class for each spatial level, derived from the geometry of the GISCO COMM_2004 dataset (based on EuroBoundary Map 2004). A generalised version of each allows for visualisation at the scale of 1:3 Million. UA Cities are also represented by a point topology that are derived from and synchronised with the GISCO STTL dataset of European Settlements. The UA city points are, when possible, synchronised to an Urban Fabric class in Corine Land Cover 2000.
In general, Urban Audit Cities have a LUZ associated. Are exceptions to this rule all Large City Audit (LCAs - code xx501 and higher) and 11 cities in France.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Cartographic representation of the Urban Audit cities

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: Area Management/restriction/regulation zones and reporting units

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Directive 2007/2/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 March 2007 establishing an Infrastructure for Spatial Information in the European Community (INSPIRE)

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: The datasets have been created for cartographic purposes.

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Source should be acknowledged: "Source: GISCO - Eurostat (European Commission)"
Copyright should be acknowledged: "Copyright: EuroGeographics for the administrative boundaries"

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: All feature classes, attribute tables and relationship classes should be present

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: All feature classes, attribute tables and relationship classes are present

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: The integrity and cardinality of the relationships (conceptual and implemented) was checked by enforcing primary and foreign key integrity constraints in Oracle. The constraints referencing domain tables were a test of domain consistency.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Errors during creation of integrity constraints.

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: No errors occurred, so the integrity of all primary and foreign keys was confirmed. All coded values are compliant to the relevant domains (except for any NULL values). The cardinality can only be confirmed where it is strict enough for this test to detect errors.

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Consistency of URAU City points and regions

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: All City points must be properly inside a City region and a generalised 1:3M City region.

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: No topology errors identified, so all points are covered by a region.

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: UA City regions must not overlap (including within generalised 3M version).

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: No topology errors identified, so regions do not overlap with each other.

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Consistency between Cities and City Kernels

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: UA City regions with a real (not null) Kernel code must be covered by the Kernel region having the same code (with a final K).

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: Only violation was a UK001C (London), where the City extends beyond the Kernel. This is a known exception, all other UA Kernels cover the equivalent UA City.

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Consistency between Urban Audit and European Settlements datasets

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: UA City regions with a real (not null) STTL code must cover at least one point in the Settlements dataset having the same STTL code (STTL_ID).

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: All UA City regions with a STTL code matched with the correct STTL point, so all regions contain the matched STTL point.

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Consistency between Urban Audit and Commune 2004 datasets

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: UA region boundaries (City, Kernel and LUZ) must be covered by the boundaries of COMM_RG_2004.

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: No topology errors identified, so UA regions boundaries are coincident with their source COMM_2004 region boundaries.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
The third Urban Audit exercise was launched in 2006. The collected data is referenced to 2004. It is managed by the Directorate General for Regional Policy in collaboration with EUROSTAT.
The URAU polygonal geometry was derived from the GISCO Communes 2004 regional feature class. Information assigning membership of each EBM 2004 commune to each of the 3 UA levels was provided at the Country level. Generalised versions were created for display at a scale of 1:3 Million.
The point geometry of the Urban Audit Cities was based on the GISCO STTL dataset of European Settlements. Points were created in 17 cases where a UA City could not be matched to a Settlement in GISCO STTL dataset.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString:
Country files listing UA status (City, Kernel and LUZ codes) of each EBM 2004 commune were joined to the geometry of the GISCO COMM_2004 regions. This was dissolved by each UA code to give the multipart regions for each UA level.
Attributes were appended to each feature class by joining pre-prepared attribute tables.
The three polygonal feature classes were generalised for display at a scale of 1:3 Million. The geometries were combined prior to generalisation using a Union, so that boundaries shared between feature classes would also share the same simplified form. Polygons below 2.25km2 were eliminated by merging into the neighbouring polygon sharing the longest border, or deleted (for small islands). At least one feature was retained for each unique City, Kernel and LUZ. The simplification used the Bend Simplify option of the Simplify Polygon tool in ArcGIS 9.2, with a reference baseline of 1500m.
UA City points were derived by matching City regions to the GISCO Settlement dataset based on proximity and name-matches. All except 17 UA Cities were matched, and STTL codes were retained as a UA City attribute. In several cases the STTL and UA City points were located outside the UA City regions (original or generalised). They were moved so that the PT falls inside the RG, while still respecting the requirements for STTL points.
The Urban Audit status of each commune was recorded by appending the City, Kernel and LUZ codes to the COMM_2004_AT attribute table.

Geometry: GISCO COMM_2004 (source EuroBoundary Map - EuroGeographics) generalised.
Attributes: Country tables listing the UA status (codes) of EBM_2004 communes (source Eurostat); Name tables listing the attributes of UA entities (source Eurostat)

gmd:definition.gco:CharacterString: Urban Audit City attribute table and generalised region geometry

Primary key. UA City identification code. The code is divided in 3 segments: - the first two characters define the country code. - The next three characters (positions 3 to 5) are an arbitrary number. Codes starting by "5" are the so called Large City Audit (LCAs) - The last character is a "C", that stands for "City"

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: The Urban Audit is influenced by Council Regulation (CE) No 322/97 of 17 February 1997 on community statistics, along with Council Regulation (EURATOM, EEC) no 1588/90 of 11 June 1990 on the transmission of the data subject to statistical confidentiality to the Statistical Office of the European Communities, stipulating the detailed rules used for receiving, processing and disseminating confidential data.
